answers.text: @eveyouthinkso mybad i phrased it wrongly. i meant the full heat as in the “who should be the one apologising” haha. I agree that the statement could’ve been better phrased anyway.

Most people were not aware of the mistreatment as most workers dare not voice out to the authorities due to the fear of being sent back to their countries after complaining against their employers.

@eveyouthinkso i mean yeah i agree that her statement isn’t very logical or properly phrased but even if there is no need to apologise then this current “issue” won’t have to exist at all but unfortunately someone thinks an apology is needed which is why i’m just curious on why the target group that needs to apologise is the government and maybe not the migrant workers employers for example? i mean no one planned for this virus to spread to the workers, definitely not the government, so why the need to give them unnecessary problems?

The central conflicting idea in this episode is whether the government has the responsibility to take care of people apart from it’s own citizens. The primary role of the government is to take care of Singaporeans, no doubt, and thus it is arguable that the government does not owe migrant workers an apology. But if we approach this from a more humanistic rather than political point of view, the question is of how we as a society should treat others, even if they are different from us. Because if we as a ‘1st world nation’ can’t treat all humans with basic respect and  demand basic standards of living, then it is very shameful and disgusting to call ourselves ‘1st world’ ...

answers.text: @failalvlgang it is the government’s responsibility because they have the power to pass laws. These laws should protect citizens and also the economy. By leaving out migrant workers from the equation, we have exposed the Achilles heel of the economy; with so many migrant workers now not being able to work, who will perform their most basic function? Protecting them is indirectly, protecting us. The people who should be paying extra taxes is not us as a society but the companies that are profiting from these arrangement. They can simply profit less.

answers.text: @spencerlahh I second this. It all boils down to one point. Do the employers have a heart for the FW well being? You don't need rules and regulations to teach/show the employers what is the right way to treat the FW. Unfortunately, these employers choose to benefit themselves by making such inhumane arrangement for the FW. It's comes down to the black nature of these employers. As an organization, now they've learnt, they should start to bang down the iron fist on these employers once the FW issues are solved.

@andreathongg ; imma @ you so you see this. .
I fully agree with you. I believe that no matter how much rules that the government could’ve set, I’m sure that there will be at least one company who will find a loophole and cut cost to boost profits. The ones who are DIRECTLY responsible for the FW are the construction companies themselves, not the government. What is the point of putting blame the organisation who sets the rules, and not the organisations who are responsible for the problem instead?
@pei._.yi deepen*

@jacqueline.chua I sure will! I hope you will think about what you can do to help the migrant community as you have said and deeper your understanding on their plight and the factors that caused this situation!
@pei._.yi and also us Singaporeans!

@jacqueline.chua I tried to help, did you? I donated money and I created resources to spread information to help with the migrant community on social media. So, your assumptions are untrue. I am just pointing out the improvements that could have been done and the obvious failure on the PAP part. Does every criticism count as an anti-PAP propaganda?Sure , please be optimistic. But don't downplay the need of an apology to the victims in this situation not only from the employers, but govt.
@jacqueline.chua and also for the contention, I'm replying in relation to the article above. Should the government apologise?

@jacqueline.chua and thats because I'm implying the government is at fault because of their lax regulations (50% success and 50% failure) which they failed to improve on over the years and let the employers exploit their workers 🤦‍♀️ yes I fully agree that the operators/employers are the most at fault. but they are not the ONLY one is what I am saying.
@andreathongg agree!

@pei._.yi I understand they are business oriented. But there is a thick line between treating your employees ethically and milking your employees inhumanly. If you don't take care of your employees they will take care of your business. These employers failed to see how lucky they are. In other countries, if they are treated like these foreign workers, they will go on strike/riot.
@andreathongg right, but unfortunately not many employers think that way which is a shame!
@jacqueline.chua And also, my contention is whether the government should or should not apologise. Not whether the blame is on other parties.

I think partially because the regulations have loopholes, allowing employers to such inhumane measures. But still, with regulations or not, as human with basic empathy, you don't need regulations to prevent you from committing such inhumane act. If the employers have the heart to treat their employees in a more humane way, we wouldn't have such problem in the first place.
@pei._.yi excuse the mistake, *having heavier penalties would deter more operators from flouting the rules

@jacqueline.chua Similar to the death penalty, having such heavy penalties would deter many people from committing murder. Despite regulations set by MOM, the govt admitted that half of the operators flouted the regulations. What does that tell you? There needs to be heavier penalties and stricter regulations which is set by the MOM. There is hardly any murders because the penalty is too severe! It is arguably undeniable that lax regulations set the foundation for the exploitation of regulations by profit hungry dorm operators! And yes, the dorm operators should apologise too! I'm not saying that they shouldn't!

@jacqueline.chua you're welcome! I believe people are entitled to their own opinions on this whole entire situation and I respect that. I thought Josephine Teo has learnt her lesson about having sex in small spaces to be more tactful with her response but... Oh well 🤷🤷

@pei._.yi I realised about her is that every response she gave wasn't tactful. I understand what she meant but she needs to sell it in a way that is humane and acceptable considering GE is around the corner. Personally, I don't wanna view her is this negative way, but still, I feel that ego is in her way.

@andreathongg I think the problem now that Josephine Teo is the Minister of MOM. Judging by this character, it's unlikely that she will allow MOM to apologise unless PR steps in. But I do believe that not all MPs think the same as her and her actions is not a reflection of the entire cabinet, but just her. The best way is to apologise and like you said, work harder to ensure better regulation of dorms and heavier penalties on dorm operators.

@pei._.yi I agree with you. But I think what would be better is that both the employers and MOM need to step up their game. But the title stated Govt. Not MOM. If we are talking about MOM doing an apology, than yes, I agree. An apology and rebuild of a better facility with the employers and at the time same time employers need to be punished for not adhering to the requirements.

@andreathongg It shows the failure of MOM regulation. There needs to be stricter regulations to ensure that the dorm operators adhere to MOM standards especially when the govt admitted that half of them flout licensing conditions per year. Hence, this reflects the poor performance of MOM which commands an apology (logically speaking).

Alright guys. My apologies for the bad analogy. I did not mean to use this as a way to express my detest. But what I wanted to say was, migrant workers will definitely not dare to demand an apology especially when they are at a potential risk of being deported. I think the question posted to Josephine was not appropriate. To ask if migrant workers have demanded an apology, doesn’t just cut it. We, as a country should be the ones that are apologising and I feel that she hasn’t been pulling her own weight in making sure that these migrant workers are safe. Once again, I apologise to all that I have offended, I’m as annoyed as everybody else about this and feel that these migrant workers deserve so much more for building up our country literally.

@gavelgang_ there can definitely be some comprimise to make it happen the govt has the power but tbh its just whether they want to or not only. i heard before on shark tank the best deals are made when everyone is a little bit uncomfortable and i think it applies here as well haha

@bradley.thm yes I stated that before if the govt were to put it into law the employers would be unhappy which can cause them not to do business in Singapore causing a crisis of shortage in labour workers. Great talk! I hope people do discuss more about issues thoroughly and see perspectives. I do agree some minor reforms should be done and this issue is not an easy one to mitigate.
@gavelgang_ i see. but im sure the govt has the power to put something into law to make something like this happen? anyway good talk bro

@bradley.thm the foreign workers are working in Singapore under a work pass that is under the employers so technically it's the employers that control the way they live, where they work and how much they get. Even though relocating govt funds is a good idea the govt wouldn't be able to direct funds to the workers directly. They can only relocate the funds to organisations that help these workers.

@gavelgang_ i agree with what u said but maybe the cost to increase quality of life for these workers doesnt have to come from thr employers. in that scenario where employers are paying out of pocket, yes it wld not be profitable anymore. but i believe the govt can find an area of huge profits (i.e casino? idk) that the sg govt can mandate a % of those profits go to helping these foreign workers in any way they seem fit. this is an uninformed suggestion but thats just what i think

@bradley.thm yes I do agree its because of their backgrounds that's why they dont have a choice, and yes there can be minor changes to the way they live here. The Singapore govt cant go on to spend their own money on these workers because these workers are not citizens, yes they help to bulid our country but they are still not singaporeans. It's up to the employers if they want to increase the pay or not and the govt can force employers to do so but at what cost? The employers wouldn't see a profit in doing business in Singapore as the govt forces them to pay workers higher and there would be a shortage in workers. In the process of educating them it would cost more money leading to more taxes. The Singapore government cannot solve the problem of other govts.

@gavelgang_ the sad part is that they dont do construction in sg for themselves. if they didnt have families im pretty sure their current salary working in singapore is enough for one person (by that i mean having enough money to buy enough food to be full and a small savings per month). from what i understand they send the majority of their income to their families back home and deal with the limited money they have left.
@gavelgang_ maybe we cld go one step further and provide further education for them to move up in life

@gavelgang_ but for the migrant workers working in construction in singapore is their BEST option. maybe its their education lvl or maybe its the poor job market in their country but u tell me who wld spend their entire savings on an agent to bring them to another country, separating them from their families and earn just enough to survive? if we dont increase their salaries the most we cld do for them is provide safe and clean housing for them
